The below story was posted on urlLink Yahoo from urlLink Reuters . Pretty cool story. If only people would realize that they don't need to see a Mel Gibson movie to be transformed by Jesus' sacrifice for us. Christ Movie Moves Man to Confess Murder HOUSTON (Reuters) - A repentant Texas man went to police after seeing Mel Gibson's controversial film "The Passion of Christ" and confessed to murdering a 19-year-old woman who was pregnant with his child, authorities said on Thursday. Police had thought Ashley Nicole Wilson, who died on Jan. 18, had hanged herself, but Dan Leach, 21, went to them on March 9 to admit that he had killed her, said Fort Bend County Sheriff's Department spokeswoman Jeannie Gage. Leach wanted to seek redemption after talking to a friend and seeing the movie about the last hours of Christ's life, she said. "He mentioned that speaking with the friend and seeing the movie 'The Passion of Christ' made him feel remorse," Gage said. Leach said he killed Wilson because she was pregnant with his child and he did not want to be involved with her anymore, she said. Wilson was found in her apartment with a suicide note describing her depression but Leach said he staged the murder to look like she had killed herself. The Houston Chronicle first reported the story in its online edition. Leach was released after his confession while police investigated and was arrested on Tuesday after a grand jury indicted him. He was being held on $100,000 bail, Gage said. The Mel Gibson film has been criticized for graphic violence and for its portrayal of the role of Jews in the death of Christ.

Below is an article that I wrote for the newsletter at urlLink Philpott Memorial Church a couple of years ago. It outlines how I came to know Jesus. The "community" that I describe is one of the things that my new church, urlLink FRWY , has as one of it's strengths. I wanted to post this on my blog to reinforce the importance of this ideal. As Connections Leader @ FRWY, reading this tonight is inspiring me to do more, be more creative, to be somebody else's Ruth and Gerald (read on and you will know what I mean). I hope you find it inspiring, whether you have a relationship with Christ or not. ******* On Sunday October 21 (2001), Pastor Lane interviewed me as a lead into his message during the contemporary service. During the interview he asked me how long I had been attending Philpott. He also asked me to share with the congregation how the church had helped me grow as a Christian. I answered the questions and then took my place in the pew. My first feelings after sitting down were relief and happiness. I was happy to be able to share my church experience with the congregation. But then a sense of disappointment crept in. There was so much more that I could have said! What could I do to share more? Quickly I thought, "Maybe a second interview?" No, I didn't think that would happen. At the end of the sermon, Lane held up a newsletter and encouraged us to read it. "That's it!!" I thought. Therefore, I submit to you this article. I hope to share more of my experience with you in way that will encourage you to be an important part of the Church you have always longed for. My wife Cindy and I began attending Philpott in September 1999. Cindy had been working on me for a long time to start going to church. The pressure increased with the birth of our second son that June. Cindy had some exposure to Christianity as a child and became a believer at age 9. She had not attended church regularly but felt the strong need to be raising our children in a Christian home. Finally that September she warned me that she was going to take the kids to church with or without me. Reluctantly, I agreed to come too. Only God could have arranged the sequence of events that first day. We arrived early as Cindy insisted that we attend Sunday School as well as a service. We asked two people in the parking lot where we should go. Just as we were asking them, Pat Harvey was getting out of her car. They told us to go with her. Pat took us into the gym and introduced us to Pastor Wayne. Wayne then introduced us to Ruth and Gerald L'Abbe. During that Sunday school class, Ruth graciously let us use her Bible. After the service Ruth and Gerald did something they said that had never done before. They invited us over for lunch. I couldn't believe how nice these complete strangers were being to us! Six weeks later Gerald helped me in praying for forgiveness and asking the Lord into my life. So many things over those six weeks helped me grow to that decision. Walter Dickson was the first person to share the Gospel with me. I had never heard it before. I also learned of the resurrection of Jesus. The truthfulness of what I was hearing really impacted me. But that wasn't all. We experienced so much love in those first weeks. A friendship emerged with Ruth and Gerald and we got together often. We started a 50 day spiritual adventure on our second Sunday. That was an immediate introduction to regular Bible study, which was a fantastic experience. We went to a Newcomers Luncheon. Jeanette Carey insisted that she hold and entertain Jordan (only 4 months old at the time). It was just what we needed to be able to enjoy our meal and converse with other people. At that Luncheon we sat with Rick and Martha Bradford. Again, we experienced a genuine interest in us that was very comforting. And our son Derek got a real kick out of Rick. Rick talked us into bringing Derek to Awana on Tuesdays. Also in those first weeks I played touch football and attended a men's breakfast. On Tuesday November 16, 1999, in my car in the Philpott parking lot, I accepted Jesus as my Saviour. I will never be the same again. That Sunday, Cindy and I dedicated our children to the Lord. Before Lane dedicated Derek and Jordan, I announced my good news to the congregation. After the service Ruth Marshall hugged each of us with tears of joy in her eyes. She had been praying for us. In the past two years we have continued to grow in our faith at Philpott. I have taken part in several adult electives, men's breakfasts, and a retreat. I learned this afternoon that my Aunt Marlene, my mom's eldest sister, is dying of cancer. Didn't really impact me that much because my mom and aunt have never really been that close. At least not as long as I can remember. I couldn't even tell you the last time I saw her. Funny thing; my mom's family. 11 kids. At some point during my lifetime, virtually every one of them have not been on speaking terms with one of their siblings at one time or another. My mom and aunt just drifted apart over the years, probably for a number of reasons. But there was my mom today in tears as she was telling Cindy and I about it. This raises some questions for me. For example, my dad and I have not spoken for eight years. And I wonder, if I found out tomorrow that he was dying of cancer, would I be in tears? As I type this, I'm unable to stir up that emotion in myself. How is it that my mom can? Maybe growing up together in a brutal, abusive childhood on the farm they experienced at the hands of their father, created a life long, deep rooted emotion for my mom. Maybe my mom is just a much more compassionate person than I am. I don't know. So in two weeks my mom is hosting a huge family meal. My aunt Marlene will be there. Her son Rick is going to drive in from Napanee for it. Some of my mom's other siblings will be there. And as I am finishing this thought, I am envisioning how emotional that day could be. It always gets me when my mom cries. Could be a tough day. Another question. What does the future hold for me? My mom's oldest brother, Glen, died 11 years ago of cancer. He was probably in his mid to late 50's. My mom is 52. That make Aunt Marlene probably 62 or 63. Now she has cancer. Neither Glen or Marlene were smokers. My mom is a heavy smoker. Will she get cancer? Will I get cancer someday? Four of my mom's brothers have had heart attacks with my Uncle Keith dying of a massive heart attack at 51 years old. Will I have a heart attack? My biggest fear is how my wife and kids would be without me. Not becasue I think they need me for survival. But if they love me even half of how much I love them, it would be very tough emotionally for them. I don't know how I could survive if I ever lost one of them. Amy's latest entry pretty much sums up the fears us parents endure. Above all, I believe in God's plan for my life, and trust in Him. It's this faith that gives me peace.

So last week was my vacation. And a week was definitely too short. I think the perfect vacation is minimum two weeks so that you can go away for the first week and then stay home and chill for the second. Going away always involves so much work. Especially when you're going camping. It takes a long time to pull out all the gear and then pack it into the car. And I'll tell you, when you're packing gear, clothes, food, etc for four people into a Malibu, you have to be methodical about it. We left on Tuesday morning, but before we left I had to do some work on the car. I have been hearing a nasty creaking sound coming out of the driver's side front brake. So on Monday I pulled the front wheels off, dismantled the calipers to lubricate them. While I was at it, I adjusted the rear drum brakes and rotated the tires. So, I spent most of Monday afternoon working on the car. Not exactly a restful part of the vacation, if you know what I mean. After finishing the brakes, I started stuffing into the car all the gear and clothes that Cindy and I had been pulling together all weekend. This left me with the cooler, canoe, bikes and othe misc. items for Tuesday morning. I had hoped to be on the road by 9 am but didn't get going until 10. After, almost 5 hours of travel (including stops at Tim's, Gas, the Town of Tweed for the propane bottles I forgot and fishing licences, we arrived at our destination: urlLink Bon Echo Provincial Park. (BTW, didn't see Elvis in Tweed). I gotta say. The Park is fantastic. Our site had great privacy. The kids shows on bats (Tues night) and frogs (Wed night) were teriffic. The park chaplain had a great kids' programme Thursday morning. There is a 375 foot high rock face directly across the lake from the park is absolutely beautiful. (Check out the picture on the above link.). There are trails and hiking to the top of the rock face, but we didn't get up there. The mosquitos, however, were plentiful and they were hungry! And the Deet just was not doing the job. Our poor kids came home looking like they had the chicken pox or something. The other downer was all the rain. It rained off and on all week. I didn't even get on my bike the whole trip. We woke up every morning to rain and the kids ate breakfast in the car each morning. We waited two full days before attempting to go canoeing. Sure enough, we weren't in the water 10 minutes when it started thundering and raining. So we went to shore and the kids swan in the lake in the rain. Then the skies cleared and we wre able to paddle over to that rock face and check out the native pictographs, etc. So, at least we were able to get in a good paddle on our trip. Friday morning we had to pack up wet gear, drive home, waste an hour in Toronto traffic, set up the tent to clean it, pack away gear and do a ton of laundry, clean a filthy car.....and so on. All in all, it was a good trip, great to spend time with the family. The kids were really great. I just wish I had that second week at home to just chill. All for now. Peace.

I was sitting here at my computer tonight when I heard some thunder roll outside. I was a little surprised because it was such a beautiful day today, with no sign of rain. For some reason tonight, after hearing that thunder, I had to go out side. It was almost as if God was saying, "Come, listen to me. Hear my power." I love thunderstorms. Ever since I was a kid, I've loved thunderstorms. I love the light show that lightening provides. I marvel at how loud thunder can get as the storm gets closer and closer. I love the sheets of rain that pour out of the sky. The sound of that rain pelting the roofs, the pavement, the puddles that the rain already created, the sound of the rain in the eavestroughs, draining down the pipes. I love it all. I can remember as a teenager just sitting in my bedroom with the widow open watching and listening to the t-storms for what seemed like hours. I remember once, when I was a young kid, visiting friends of the family. They lived on Balsam Ave., near Gage Park in an old house with a large covered veranda, much like the house I live in now. I remember thinking how cool it was to sit outside during a storm. To be so close to it. To hear it better than you do inside the house. Yet I was still sheltered; not getting wet. That was the beginning of my fascination. And to this day, I still like to just go outside, and enjoy a good thunderstorm. For some reason, it gives me peace. A kind of meditation. And the feeling has grown further since I found God almost 5 years ago. And I sensed Him tonight. I prayed to Him. And as fast as the storm came, it went again. And I had to come in and get this out of my head and into the computer...
